turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Paxcow says Daddy's going to do something really bad. He--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Who is this Paxcow? Is he like the boogeyman?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: He's a ghost. But he's a good ghost.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: There are no ghosts, Ellie. I want you to go to sleep and forget all this nonsense.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Will you at least call and make sure daddy's okay?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Of course I will.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Please hurry.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I will. Come and kiss me.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yaay!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Hurrts! It hurrrrts!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Anyone who can scream that loud isn't ready for intensive care just yet-- looks like she just skinned her knee.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: No-I guess not.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yayyy!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Have you got a death-wish, Ellen?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, I thought it was safe--

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I want to look around, daddy-- may I?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: For a little while.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: And that someone cared enough about that animal to mark the spot.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: To remember.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's what I think. I heard Missy Dandridge tell Mom when Church was fixed he wouldn't cross the road so much.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, it's always better to take precautions--but I'm sure Church will be all right, honey...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: In the end he's gonna croak, isn't he?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Lovey...Church might be still alive when you're in a high school...and that's a very long time.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It doesn't seem long to me. It seems short. I think the whole thing about pets dying s-s-sucks!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Good God! Where'd you hear that?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Missy Dandridge. And she says it's a operation!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yeah, I know...how are things out there in Chicagoland?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Fine...except when Mom was airing Gage's diaper rash, he walked away and got into Grampa's study and pooped in Grampa's favorite chair.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes...I guess so. He was sleeping on the front porch when I left.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Cause I had a bad dream about him. I dreamed he got hit by a car and you and Mr. Crandall buried him in the Pet Sematary.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Is he really all right?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Because you promised.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I've noticed it, too. I'll cough up the money, Ellen.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I hate that smell.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: She's in bed. She was throwing up. Ever since Mrs. Rogers called and said Missy--

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: That's enough, Ellen.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Ellie? What's wrong?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No more chocolate chip cookies.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Missy made the best chocolate chip cookies in the world--even Mom said so. Now there won't be any more because she's gonna be dead forever!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What's up, sugar?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Daddy, do you think Missy Dandridge went to heaven?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: At school Michael McDowell said she was gonna fry in hell. Michael McDowell says all sewersides fry in hell.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, I think Michael McDowell is so full of shit he probably squeaks when he walks, my dear.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: But don't you dare say that.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I won't...is Missy in heaven, do you think?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I don't know, honey. Different people believe all sorts of different things happen to us when we die. Some believe in heaven or hell. Some think we're born again as little children--

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sure, carnation. Like in that movie you rented, Audrey Rose.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, it's actually reincarnation, but you get the idea. And some people think we just wink out...like a candle flame when the wind blows hard.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Do you believe that?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I think we go on. I'm not sure what happens after we die, but yeah-- I have faith in that.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You believe in it.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, faith's a little more than just believing.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, here we are, sitting in my chair. Do you think my chair will be here tomorrow?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Then you have faith in that. But we don't know it will be; after all, some crazed chair-burglar might break in while we're away and steal it, right?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm not tired!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'm sure you're not.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Then why do I have to go to bed?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Because your mother and I need the rest, sugar. Now buzz.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Ellie--

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And I'm going to eat his breakfast cereal, too, even though it tastes like boogers. And...and...

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Be good to your mother, darlin'. She needs you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Come with us, daddy. Please come with us!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'll be there in three days--four at the most. I've got to get the electricity shut off and square things with your school so the truant officer ain't after you, and--

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Do you swear?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I swear.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Jud Crandall. I live just across the road.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm Rachel. Thanks again for saving the wandering minstrel boy, here.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No harm, no foul. But you want to watch out for that road. Those damn trucks go back and forth all day and most of the night.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Excuse me, Mr. Crandall--I've got to change this kid. It's nice to meet you.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Same here. Come over and visit when you get the chance.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: How can you call it a good thing? A graveyard for pets killed in the road! Built and maintained by broken- hearted children!

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Well, but Missus Creed! It ain't quite that way, deah!

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No--but if he drops by, I'll tell him to call you.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Jud, do you remember the name of the student that died on Louis's first day at work? The one that was hit by a car?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Was it Pascow?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh, I think 'twas. If I see Louis come home before I go to bed, I'll tell him to--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Don't bother. I'm coming home.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Hey--they actually found the place!

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Movin' in's mighty thirsty work. I usually sit out on my porch of an evening and pour a couple of beers over m'dinner. Come on over and join me, if you want.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, maybe I----

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You need a glass?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Good for you.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: God, that's fine.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ain't it just? The man who invented beer, Louis, that man was having a prime day for himself.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What were you listening to?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Allman Brothers.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: The Eat A Peach album. God, they were good before drugs and bad luck caught up with them. Listen to this, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: I like rock and roll. No...I guess that's too mild. I love it. Since my ears started to die out on me, it's the only music I can really hear. And since my wife died...I dunno, some- times a little rock and roll fills up night. Not always, but sometimes.  One more time--welcome to Ludlow. Hope your time here will be a happy one.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: The one that goes into the woods--sure.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: That road--and those Orinco trucks-- are the two main reasons it's there.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What's at the end of it?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You folks ready to go on?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Who owns the woods up ahead? Paper companies?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Nope. The Micmac Indians. What's up ahead is all that's left of their tribal lands.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Not yet...how much further is it?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Aw, you'll be okay. Less than a mile.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I can hardly read these.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh--they get older as you go toward the middle.  Pete LaVasseur's dog is buried there...  the Stoppard boys' racing pigeon that Missus Cowley's cat got...and I think that's the cat himself right there, although it's been so many years I can't tell for sure.  Missy Ellen! Come over here just a minute!

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No--not right out loud. Their stones speak...or their markers. Even if the marker ain't nothing but a tin can someone wrote on with a Magic Marker, it speaks. Ain't that so, Louis?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I think it is so, Ellie.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: My wife is not crazy about cemeteries of any kind. As you may have noticed.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Me neither. But I believe in knowing your enemy.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Did you tell me Rachel took the kids back to Chicago for a few days?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: For Ellie's birthday, yes. I didn't go because her old man thinks I'm a shit and the feeling is heartily re- ciprocated...they'll be back tomorrow night. Jud, what's this about?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Well, there's a dead cat over here on the edge of my lawn, Louis. I think it might be your daughter's.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Church? Oh. Oh, Jesus.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: It's Church.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: I'm sorry. At least it don't look like he suffered.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Ellie will, though. She'll suffer plenty.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Loved that cat pretty well, didn't she?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Bagged cat. What a mess.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You going to bury him in the Pet Sematary?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Going to tell Ellie?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Seems like you told me about a promise you made--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No need to apologize.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Maybe when they call I'll just tell Ellie I haven't seen the damn cat around. You know?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Jud, this is crazy. It's going to be almost dark before we get back.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: It's going to be dark before we even get where we're going, Louis. But we can do it...and we're going to.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: But--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Does she love the cat?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes, but--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Then come on.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: What say, Louis?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Nothing.  Do we plant him on the outer circle or start a new one?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: We're still not where we're going.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: The place we're going is on the other side of that.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: We can't climb over that. We'll break our necks!

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No. We won't. I have climbed it a time or two before, and I know all the places to step. Just follow me...move easy...don't look down...and don't stop. If you stop, you'll crash through for sure.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'm not climbing that.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Give me the cat. I'll take care of it myself.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No, you shouldn't have stopped. But you got away with it. Important thing is are you sure you're all right?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes.  Where are we going, Jud?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You'll see before long. Let's go.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Micmacs used to call it Little God Swamp.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Is there quicksand?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: There's a lot of funny things down this way, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You're telling me.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: It's funny, all right.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Just don't stop, Louis. You don't ever want to stop down here in Little God.  And you don't ever want to look behind you, whatever you hear.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Almost there, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You keep saying that.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: This time I mean it.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: This was their burying ground, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Whose burying ground?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: The Micmac Indians. I brought you here to bury Ellen's cat.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Why? For God's sake, why?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: I had my reasons, Louis. We'll talk later. All right?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I guess so...but...

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You want to rest a bit before you start?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: No, I'm okay. Will I really be able to dig him a grave? The soil looks thin.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Soil's thin, all right. But you'll manage.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What are those for?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Your cairn.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Doesn't look like they last long.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Don't worry about that.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Jud, why am I doing all this?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Because it's right.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: But--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: No buts! Accept what's done, Louis. What we done was right. Another time it might not be, but tonight it was... at least I hope to Christ it was. Now you make your call...but not a word about tonight.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: I most generally don't start before noon, but this looks like an exception.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What did we do, Jud?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Why, saved a little girl from being unhappy...that's all. Drink up, Louis!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I tried to tell myself I buried him alive. You know--Edgar Allan Poe meets Felix the Cat. But...

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Wouldn't wash?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: No. I'm a doctor. I know death when I see it, and Church was dead. He smells horrible and he uses his claws, but he's alive...and I feel like I'm going crazy. It was that place, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh. It was the rag-man told me about the place--Stanley Bouchard. Us kids just called him Stanny B. He was half Micmac himself.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Can I have another one?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: I guess it wouldn't hurt.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: They buried their dead and for a long time their dead stayed buried. Then something happened. Half the tribe died in a season. The rest moved on. They said a Wendigo had soured the ground.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Wendigo?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Spirit of the north country. Not a good spirit. Wendigos are great liars and tricksters, according to the stories. And if one touches you...

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You and this old Indian rag-man--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Stanny B. did for me what I did for you last night, Louis. Only I wasn't alone when Spot came back.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Well, she was a little upset at first, and that's why I thought you ought to hold your peace when you talked to your people last night...you did, didn't you, Louis?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Why, then, things should be fine.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: A little upset is all she was? Because I'll tell you, Jud, my brains feel a little like a nuclear reactor on the edge of a meltdown.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: She got used to the idea. Spot lived another four years. He died peacefully in the night that second time, and I buried him in the Pet Sematary...where his bones still lie.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: A man doesn't always know why he does things, Louis. I think I did it because your daughter ain't ready for her favorite pet to die.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ellie's a little scared of death. And the main reason Ellie's that way is because your wife is a lot scared of death. Now you just go ahead and tell me I'm wrong.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Rachel not feeling well?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well...a touch of the flu...

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Out of the mouths of babes, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: This babe has said enough.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Poor Missy. God, I was sorry to hear. I remember when she was no older'n Ellen there, walking down to the store with her Raggedy Anne doll draggin' behind her in the dust. I don't know why God takes someone like her, who should have a bunch of years still in front of them, and lets an old shit like me just go on and on.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: My father used to have a saying, Jud-- "God sees the truth, but waits."

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh...how is your cat, Louis?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: It's Ellie's cat.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Nope. He's your cat now.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Your father-in-law packs a wallop, for an old guy. He and his wife gone back to Chicago?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: No...squatting out there at the Holiday Inn like a couple of vultures. He really thinks Rachel's going to go back with them. Her and Ellie.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Louis--

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Jud, I buried my son today and I'm very tired. I wonder if we could just--

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: You're thinking of things best not thought of, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'm thinking about going to bed.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: --but I think the thought has crossed your mind.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Shit! Look at this mess!

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Ayuh--it's a mess, all right.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: I know the Micmacs thought it was a holy place...and then they thought it was a cursed place. That's why they moved on.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Because something called a wendigo soured the ground.

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: And because the dead walked.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'll bite--what's the bottom of the truth, Jud?

turns.speaker: JUD
turns.text: Why...that sometimes dead is better. That's all. Sometimes dead is better.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I want to wake up. I want to wake up, that's all. I--

turns.speaker: PASCOW
turns.text: The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. Don't go on, doc. No matter how much you feel you have to. There's more power here than you know.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Please, I want to wake up. Leave me alone. It's not my fault you died; you were as good as dead when they brought you in--

turns.speaker: PASCOW
turns.text: The power of this place is old and always restless. Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Leave me alone!

turns.speaker: PASCOW
turns.text: Remember.

turns.speaker: PASCOW
turns.text: The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You don't understand--

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'll tell you where the ground is sour--the ground in my heart is sour. Let me tell you something else, Vic-baby: Wrong is wrong.

turns.speaker: PASCOW
turns.text: Timmy Baterman. That was wrong.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Don't talk like an asshole even if you are just a bit of underdone potato or a blot of mustard.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Let her go. It's cool.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Louis, the house is beautiful.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: And Buckaroo Banzai.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Come on--let's parole 'em.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Gage's gone!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Jesus, the road!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Thank you. Thank you so much.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes--thanks. I'm Louis Creed.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: The movers--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes--I know. This path, Louis? Where does it go?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I don't have the slightest idea. When I saw the house, this field was under four feet of snow.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You're not really going over to have a beer with that old guy, are you?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, I've got a million questions about the area, and---

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: ---and you'll end up doing a free consultation on his arthritis or urinary problems and---

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Did you see his shirt?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: My God!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: It's beautiful!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I think it's rather extraordinary.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Extraordinarily morbid, maybe.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: She's finally asleep.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: She was a little over-excited, that's all. Poor kid.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: It was that place. That creepy cemetery up in the woods. Whatever disease the kids in this town have got, I don't want Ellie to catch it.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Jesus, Rachel, what's got into you?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Do you think I didn't hear her tonight, crying as if her heart would break? Here she is thinking Church is going to die.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Don't be silly. Church is not going to die.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: According to what Mr. Crandall says, the road's a lot more dangerous than the operation. Church will be just the same. Well--almost the same--and we won't have to worry about him getting turned into catburgers by one of those damn Orinco trucks.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: That's enough of that kind of talk!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I just said--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I know what you just said. Ellie, clear your place.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You'll be fine, Ellie. Now you can be excused. Go and wash your face.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: And Church will be fine.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Well, honey...you know that...

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Thank you, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, you're welcome. Only if some- thing should go wrong while he's under the gas--it's a one-in-a-thousand shot, but it happens--you explain to her.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Getting there.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I got eggs down here!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Good d--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I heard you tonight.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I thought maybe you did. I know you don't approve of the subject being raised--

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: That's not true. The subject scares me. Because of Zelda.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm sorry I couldn't go with you to Missy's funeral. And that I blew up when we went to that silly animal graveyard.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: That's forgotten.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Not by me, it isn't. I know how badly I acted, how unfair I was. It's just that I..you know.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Yes, I guess I do.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm going to try to do better.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You're doing fine.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You better get going, hon.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Oh Louis, I just don't know about this--

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Louis, are you sure?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'm sure.
